title: What will be the approval rating for the Russian government in December 2017?
preds: I am making this forecast as I believe Russian citizens will generally be satisfied with their country on an international level as there is a strong desire for Russia to project her power. Recent world events have shown that Russia has a strong influence on geopolitical events and can exert power to influence situations in her national interest. The Russian economy has recovered to some extent from international sanctions and has proven to be resilient against external forces. Russia has been able to effectively bolster the regime of Bashar Al-Assad against the wishes of Western governments. The annexation of Crimea was also a success for Russia as Western response has been weak. Russian foreign policy and military strategy is highly lateral and of an asymmetric nature. The Soviet concept of Maskirovka is highly effective. Russia is once again a great world power and the unipolar world of the post Soviet era has come to an end, with Russia, USA and China formking a troika of sorts.

Had time to look into the +10 point increase in December 2003. I'm attributing that outlier to Putin's United Russia party victory [1] and 4 consecutive years of economic growth [1, 2, 3] There's been some economic recovery in 2017 but it slowed in Q3 [4]. A strong second quarter got some modest increases in approval rating: April was +3 while May and June were modest 1 point increases that were sustained until Q3 when approval dropped down again with slowed economic growth. A brief history of Russia.
[1] http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-17840446 Economic history of Russia.
[2] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_history_of_the_Russian_Federation#2000-2007 History of United Russia including 2003 election
[3] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Russia World Bank Report on Russian Economy in 2017
[4] https://openknowledge.worldbank.org/bitstream/handle/10986/28930/30-11-2017-17-58-52-forwebNovFINALRERENGfull.pdf?sequence=7&isAllowed=y
The data is unreliable. Regardless, Putin maintains a strong cult of personality status in the face of any opposition.
The Russian government more closely satisfies the national need for pride
Historic trends.  Will not change in the short-term.

The more information that is disclosed about Russia and its' meddling in the United States Democratic system plus other Countries, there will be significant displeasure by many and with the education of the American, Russian and World global people/community, the less approval will be given to Putin and his corrupt style.
I,m giving Russia same approval rating as the pothus
The published numbers are questionable, but that said, Putin's leadership does seem to be popular.
It won’t be real. But it will be reported this way. Fear / propaganda

Aligning with distribution of historical monthly positive/negative point change. May not have time to fully examine the tails of the distribution to see whether a case could be made that a larger than expected point jump should be anticipated. I've looked only at the March 2014 jump of +11 points which I attribute to the events associated with and culminating in the annexation of Crimea on 18 March [1]. Nothing like that happening now and I don't think the elections would warrant that kind of a jump (probably won't have time to dig into the distribution for assumed election impacts either).  [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Annexation_of_Crimea_by_the_Russian_Federation#Russian_response
catching up to consensus and adding a little based on forecasts of those I'm following on this question.
Putin reelection campaign kicking off, and a surge in nationalism will keep the government's approval well above 51%.
Based on Levada tables and current sentiment among my emigrant friends.

According to Levada it was 57 in August.
https://www.levada.ru/en/2017/09/26/approval-ratings-of-government-institutions/
Russian Patriotism is a powerful force.

The approval ratings for the government have been dropping gradually over the fall and winter. This might be partially due to recent events, but is probably also influenced by the upcoming elections and the usual tactics of politicians dealing with opponents. However, I don't see anything that would cause a large drop or rise in approval ratings for December.
Currently at 42%, it rarely sees a change larger than 4% but it was at 48% in October
November was only 42 (I think) and things seem to be dropping. Plus they got banned from upcoming winter Olympics.
Putin's handling of political opponents prior to election
His approval rating has been between 80-90% all year. There is no reason to think it would suddenly drop so much in a few days.
Put in is well liked in Russia
The recent trend is a downward decline, and in the past year ~17% of months have experienced a 6+ change in approval rating.
Approval rating for the Gov't of Russia by whom? The Russian people? As far as I know, the Putin-led government is generally popular with Russia's populace; this will not change any time soon.
Based on November, it should be < 48, but i believe it has a strong chance of recovering to pre-November levels.
Statistically it will remain much the same

The november rating is 42. The average rating is 45.77. The monthly diff from one month to the next is on average 2.76. The chance of a 6 point increase is 3.77% historically. And the chance of a 9 point increase is ~1% historically
The peoples of Russia are glad to know of Russia's success in Syria and the increasing influence on the world stage. They believe Putin know's what he's doing, however domestic affairs he is lacking
Current approval is 42 and trending down. There have not typically been wide swings between November and December
The number tend to fluctuate between 48 and 51, except for novermber.
The foreign minister standing up for Russia against Boris Johnson might give the Government approval rating a bit of boost.
42 in Nov and has been trending downward

Base rate looking at the last two years is 48.1% with only one occasion (09/17) more than 51. 
Could not find news which would explain the drop to 42 in November, but it seems unlikely to climb by so many points in one month judging from past changes in approval ratings.
Looks like it is 42% right now
Seasonal increase. Check every December back to 2013.
Russia's moves out of the Syrian conflict, improved relations with the U.S. and a lowering of tensions in The Ukraine will all contribute to a higher approval rating for the Russian Government.
Based on ratings history and recent events.

http://news.gallup.com/poll/223382/russians-happier-putin-country-direction.aspx?utm_source=alert&utm_medium=email&utm_content=morelink&utm_campaign=syndication Russians Happier With Putin Than With Country's Direction 80% of Russians approve of Putin's leadership
52% believe country's leadership is taking them in right direction
60% approve of job performance of country's leadership WASHINGTON, D.C. -- Russians' support of President Vladimir Putin looks unshakable ahead of his bid for re-election in March 2018, with his approval ratings at a buoyant 80% in 2017. But underneath, Russians are less sure about whether their country's leadership is taking them in the right direction. While not the lowest on record, the 52% of Russians who believe their country's leadership is taking them in the right direction is the lowest in years, and it suggests that Russians continue to hold their country's leader to a different standard than they do their country's leadership in general. Russians Approve of Putin, Less Sure of Country's Leadership
Putin ended speculation Wednesday about whether he would run for president again. If he wins again, he will be in office until 2024, enshrining his status as the longest-serving leader of Russia since Joseph Stalin. Putin has been in office, as either president or prime minister, since 2000. Based on his recent approval ratings, Putin's record is likely secure. Russians' support for their president remains undiminished from the high ratings they have given him since Crimea became part of Russia in 2014. His personal brand since then has been immune to any challenges on the domestic and international fronts, including plunging oil prices, years of recession and Western sanctions over Moscow's actions in Ukraine. The country's leadership in general has not been as invulnerable -- and may, in fact, be absorbing most of the blame for the country's recent economic troubles. Although it rallied to a record-high 73% in 2014, the percentage of Russians who believe their leadership is taking them in the right direction has continued to fall. The percentage who say leadership is heading in the wrong direction doubled (from 11% to 22%) in that same period. Russians' approval ratings of the job performance of the country's leadership more generally, while still at a majority level, have also faltered. After soaring as high as 65% in 2015, Russians' approval has edged down to 60% -- still far lower than Putin's approval rating. Riding a groundswell of national pride after Crimea, the situation in Ukraine and the Sochi Olympics, Putin's approval ratings and Russians' faith in their country's leadership soared in 2014. Positivity colored nearly all aspects of Russians' lives that year -- even as oil prices and the ruble collapsed. The rally appears to have been short-lived in many regards. Russians' ratings of their lives have inched downward each subsequent year and they are increasingly finding it difficult to get by on their current incomes. Russians' faith in their country's leadership in general has also waned. But the rising uncertainty among Russians about their country's leadership will likely have little effect, if any, on who they choose to lead it. SURVEY METHODS
These results are based on face-to-face interviews with 2,000 adults in Russia, aged 15 and older, conducted June 9-Aug. 20, 2017. For results based on the total sample of national adults, the margin of sampling error is ±2.5 percentage points. The margin of error reflects the influence of data weighting. In addition to sampling error, question wording and practical difficulties in conducting surveys can introduce error or bias into the findings of public opinion polls. People living in remote or difficult-to-access areas in the Far North, North Caucasus and Far East (Nenets autonomous region, Yamalo-Nenets autonomous region, Chukotsk region) were excluded. The excluded areas represent about 20% of the population.
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  I note also that these interviews were months ago (June 9-Aug 20).
Putin will use Olympic issue to play on Nationalism.

It declined to 42% in Nov. Add to that Olympics and I think it will probably go down... unless Putin can turn this into another story about the world being unfair and cause a rally around the flag event.
It has gone down from 51, to 48, to 42 in November. Flipping. The Olympic fiasco probably does not help.

This is difficult. Currently the rating is 42 and for the past ten years the six percent leap has happened approximately only once per year. A couple of those times has been around December which might or might not be a coincidence. Furthermore, the rating has been at least 48 for the past five months before November so the drop was quite substantial. Not sure if the situation with the Olympics might affect this but I think it would more affect Putin's rating. Therefore, I think the chances for the 6+% jump is about 15-25% now and the chance for a reaching 51 is about 5%. I'll say: Less than 48 - 75%
Between 48 and 51, inclusive - 21
More than 51 - 4%

Eyeballing the data from last months. 
Nov. 2017 was 42 & I didn't see big jumps in approval ratings from one month to the next --> more probability mass for "<48".

Hard to say.  Every time the President of the United States does something stupid or the rest of the United States carries on as if Putin were omniscient and omnipotent, Putin's numbers go up.  Stay tuned.
48 or above last 5 months, 48 or above 9 of last 12 months. Going with raw percent here.
